{{Transhumanism}} '''''Democratic transhumanism''''', a term coined by Dr. [[James Hughes (sociologist)|James Hughes]] in 2002, refers to the stance of [[transhumanist]]s (advocates for the development and use of [[human enhancement]] technologies) who espouse [[Liberal democracy|liberal]], [[social democracy|social]] and/or [[Radical democracy|radical democratic]] political views.<ref name="Hughes 2001">{{cite journal| author = [[James Hughes (sociologist)|Hughes, James]]| title = Politics of Transhumanism| year = 2001 | url = http://www.changesurfer.com/Acad/TranshumPolitics.htm| accessdate=2007-01-26}}</ref><ref name="Hughes 2002">{{cite journal| author = Hughes, James| title = Democratic Transhumanism 2.0| year = 2002 | url = http://www.changesurfer.com/Acad/DemocraticTranshumanism.htm| accessdate=2007-01-26}}</ref><ref name="Hughes 2003">{{cite journal| author = Hughes, James| title = Better Health through Democratic Transhumanism| year = 2003 | url = http://archives.betterhumans.com/Columns/Column/tabid/79/Column/240/Default.aspx| accessdate=2007-01-26}}</ref><ref name="Hughes 2004">{{cite book| author = Hughes, James| title = [[Citizen Cyborg]]: Why Democratic Societies Must Respond to the Redesigned Human of the Future| publisher = Westview Press| year = 2004| isbn = 0-8133-4198-1}}</ref>
According to Hughes, the ideology "stems from the assertion that human beings will generally be [[happiness|happier]] when they take [[human agency|rational control]] of the natural and social forces that control their lives."<ref name="Hughes 2002">Hughes 2002</ref> The [[ethics|ethical]] foundation of democratic transhumanism rests upon [[rule utilitarianism]] and [[biocentrism (ethics)|non-anthropocentric]] [[personhood theory]].<ref name="Hughes 1996">{{cite journal| author = Hughes, James| title = Embracing Change with All Four Arms: A Post-Humanist Defense of Genetic Engineering| year = 1996 | url = http://www.changesurfer.com/Hlth/Genetech.html| accessdate=2007-01-26}}</ref>
While raising objections both to [[right-wing politics|right-wing]] and [[left-wing politics|left-wing]] [[Techno-progressivism#Contrasting stance|bioconservatism]], and [[libertarian transhumanism]], Hughes aims to encourage democratic transhumanists and their potential [[progressivism|progressive]] allies to unite as a [[new social movement]] and influence [[biopolitical]] [[public policy]].<ref name="Hughes 2002" /><ref name="Hughes 2004">Hughes 2004</ref>
An attempt to expand the middle ground between [[technorealism]] and [[techno-utopianism]], democratic transhumanism can be seen as a radical form of [[techno-progressivism]].<ref name="Carrico 8-2005">{{cite journal| author = [[Dale Carrico|Carrico, Dale]]| title = Listen, Transhumanist!| year = 2005 | url = http://amormundi.blogspot.com/2005/08/listen-transhumanist.html| accessdate=2007-01-27}}</ref>
Appearing several times in Hughes' work, the term "radical" (from Latin ''rādīx, rādīc-'', root) is used as an adjective meaning ''of or pertaining to the root'' or ''going to the root''. His central thesis is that [[emerging technologies]] and [[radical democracy]] can help [[citizen]]s overcome some of the ''root causes'' of inequalities of [[Power (philosophy)|power]].<ref name="Hughes 2002"/>
==Trends== Hughes has identified 15 "left futurist" or "left techno-utopian" trends and projects that could be incorporated into democratic transhumanism:<ref name="Hughes 2001">Hughes 2001</ref> {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} *[[Afrofuturism]] *[[Assistive technology]]-enabled [[disabled]] people *[[Biopunk]] science fiction and movement *[[Body modification]] culture *[[Cyborg feminism]]/[[cyberfeminism]] *[[Feminist science fiction]] *[[Lesbian science fiction]], [[Gay science fiction]], [[List of media portrayals of bisexuality|Bisexual]] science fiction, and [[Transgender]] science fiction *[[Nanosocialism]] {{col-2}} *[[Free software movement]] *Post-[[A Darwinian Left|Darwinian leftism]] *[[Postcyberpunk]] science fiction *[[Post-work]]/[[guaranteed minimum income]] movement *[[Technogaianism]] *[[Up-wing politics]] *[[Viridian design movement]] {{col-end}}
==List of democratic transhumanists== This section contains an alphabetically ordered list of notable individuals who have identified themselves or been identified by Hughes as advocates of democratic transhumanism:<ref>{{cite web|title=Cyborg Democracy|url=http://ieet.org/index.php/IEET/cybdem}}</ref> {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} *Ben Hyink *[[Charles Stross]] *[[Jamais Cascio]] *[[George Dvorsky]] *[[Giulio Prisco]] *[[Justice De Thézier]] *[[Ken MacLeod]] {{col-2}} *[[Mark Alan Walker]] *[[Martine Rothblatt]] *Pablo Stafforini *Philip Shropshire *[[Ramez Naam]] *[[Riccardo Campa]] *Robin Green {{col-end}}
==Criticism== {{Democracy}} {{Expand section|date=March 2010}} Science journalist [[Ronald Bailey]] wrote a review of ''[[Citizen Cyborg]]'' in his online column for [[Reason (magazine)|''Reason'' magazine]] in which he offered a critique of democratic transhumanism and a defense of [[libertarian transhumanism]].<ref name="Bailey 2005">{{cite journal| author = Bailey, Ronald | title = Trans-Human Expressway: Why libertarians will win the future | year = 2005 | url = http://www.reason.com/news/show/34971.html | accessdate=2006-02-05}}</ref><ref name="Bailey 2009">{{cite journal| author = Bailey, Ronald | title = Transhumanism and the Limits of Democracy | year = 2009 | url = http://reason.com/news/show/133074.html | accessdate = 2009-05-01}}</ref>
Critical theorist [[Dale Carrico]] defended democratic transhumanism from Bailey's criticism.<ref name="Carrico 5-2005">{{cite journal| author = Carrico, Dale | title = Bailey on the CybDemite Menace | year = 2005 | url = http://amormundi.blogspot.com/2005/05/bailey-on-cybdemite-menace.html | accessdate = 2006-02-05}}</ref> However, he would later criticize democratic transhumanism himself on [[technoprogressive]] grounds.<ref name="Carrico 2-2009">{{cite journal| author = Carrico, Dale | title = James Hughes Flogs for the Robot Cult | year = 2009 | url = http://amormundi.blogspot.com/2009/02/james-hughes-flogs-for-robot-cult.html | accessdate = 2010-03-27}}</ref>
